subject: Ethics
title: Pacifism as Moral Stance
description: A fast breakdown of Pacifism as Moral Stance for builders.

hook.text: Gandhi freed India without firing a shot. But could nonviolence have stopped Hitler?

buildup.text: Pacifism holds that violence is always wrong, even in self-defense or to prevent greater harm.

discovery.text: Absolute pacifists like Quakers refuse all war. Conditional pacifists oppose most war but allow exceptions.

twist.text: Critics call pacifism a privilegeâ€”easy to practice when someone else fights to protect your freedom.

climax.text: Yet every war begins with the belief that violence will solve the problem. Pacifists ask: has it ever?

punchline.text: Violence promises solutions. Peace requires harder work.

quiz.question: What is the main criticism of absolute pacifism?
options: Nonviolent movements have never achieved meaningful political change
Pacifism is a privilegeâ€”it's easy to reject violence when others protect you
Pacifism is illegal under international law during times of war
